content:
@Brock Whittaker, how do you feel about https://github.com/zulip/zulip/issues/7995? It's a request we've gotten several times.

One reason against would be if we plan on changing the dimensions of the banner that we want users to add in the near or mid future.
Can you explain your reason against it? I read that a couple times over but for some reason couldn't figure out what you mean.
Semi-related to that... are we really sticking with this logo? I think we need to put much more effort on the consistency of the brand (not to sound too corporaty)

Few things:

  • we need to ensure that a single green color is the color we use, we definitely have 4-5 that we use right now
  • the text often varies - its size, sometimes the font etc
  • if we had a better icon/logo it could stand better without the text itself
For example, Facebook have just their `F' in the upper left, Slack and FB Messenger don't have any logo at all
Also, if we keep the logo to be a single thing, and not a combination of two with custom alignments etc, it would be easier to whitelabel if necessary.

I'm not in love with our current logo, but for Brock: what I mean is that the current slot has space for say a 30px by 200px logo. Let's say we add an option that allows orgs to upload a replacement logo, and we advertize it as roughly a 30px by 200px spot.

Then, say a few months later we change the design of the nav bar area so that now there is only room for a 30px by 100px logo. All of our users will now have to go change their uploaded logos, which is a fairly big annoyance (i.e. more likely is that we will just never change the size of that whitespace.)

Or, let's say a few months later we want to change that corner to be a workplace switcher, or settings dropdown, or anything else. I think allowing custom logos there will make it harder to make such a change.

An alternative would be to just use the realm avatar there and put the name of the org in text.

30x200 is a super weird measurement anyways. My thought for this however is simple; let them upload any logo up to a 4:1 ratio (just a tad more horizontal than ours currently), and then we just make our designs around that, which I think is super feasible given that 4:1 means 120px wide, which is quite narrow.
And I think you can always find space in a page to put in a 120px wide logo.
cool, I think that's a fine solution.
